questions.explanation: Secreting Cells Location Function CCK (Cholecystokinin) I cells (Option C) Duodenum Jejunum Stimulates : Pancreatic enzyme secretion Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion Gallbladder contraction (Release of bile) Growth of exocrine pancreas Inhibits : Gastric emptying Gastrin G cells (Option A ruled out) Stomach (antrum) Duodenum Stimulates: Gastric acid secretion Mucosal growth Secretin S cells (Option D ruled out) Duodenum Stimulates: Pepsin secretion Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion Biliary bicarbonate secretion Growth of exocrine pancreas Inhibits: Gastrin release and gastric acid secretion Motilin Mo cells (Option B ruled out) Duodenum and jejunum Stimulates: Gastric motility Intestinal motility Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Physiology, 14th edition, Pg 792

questions.question: The correct sequence of events during vomiting are? 1. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter 2. Strong contractions in the stomach 3. Inspiration against a closed glottis 4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter 5. Relaxation of upper esophageal sphincter 6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine
questions.explanation: Small Intestine : Reverse peristalsis pushes intestinal contents back into the stomach, possibly introducing bile into the vomit. Relaxation of Pyloric Sphincter : In severe cases, the pyloric sphincter relaxes, facilitating the expulsion of gastric and duodenal contents. Inspiration Against a Closed Glottis : A deep breath is taken while the glottis remains closed, creating negative pressure in the thoracic cavity. Strong Contractions in the Stomach : Abdominal muscles and diaphragm contract, increasing intragastric pressure, propelling contents upward. Relaxation of Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES) : LES relaxes, allowing stomach contents to move into the esophagus. Relaxation of Upper Esophageal Sphincter (UES) : UES relaxes, allowing vomitus to exit through the mouth Step Description 1. Relaxation of LES LES relaxes to allow stomach contents to move into the esophagus. 2. Strong Contractions in Stomach Abdominal and diaphragm muscles contract to propel stomach contents upward. 3. Inspiration Against Closed Glottis Deep breath with glottis closed creates negative pressure for expulsion. 4. Relaxation of UES UES relaxes, allowing vomitus to exit the mouth. 5. Reverse Peristalsis in Small Intestine Reverse peristalsis pushes intestinal contents back into the stomach. 6. Relaxation of Pyloric Sphincter In severe vomiting, pyloric sphincter relaxes, aiding in expulsion. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Pg 490
